Department of Chemical Engineering Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) San 31 Hyoja-Dong Nam-Gu Pohang 790-784 Republic of Korea Graphical abstract Various contents of La (1–10wt.%) were added to Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst to improve its catalytic activity and long-term stability for CO methanation. The optimum amount of La for the highest CO conversion is obtained at 1wt.% La addition for fresh catalysts, whereas at 5wt.% La for aged catalyst. During a long term ageing test at a high severity condition (850°C, space velocity=250,000h−1 and 40% steam in the feed), catalysts having 0–3wt% La rapidly lose their activity at the initial 10h period due to the sintering of Ni particles, and this is followed by slower degradation due to the thermal sintering of the support alumina. Catalysts having higher La contents (5–10wt.%) exhibit an increase in the CO conversion at a certain period, which is attributed to the uncovering effect of La on the Ni surface through the agglomeration of dispersed La into aggregates. For fresh catalysts, the CO conversion and turnover frequency are highest at 1wt.% La and 7wt.% La, respectively. For aged catalysts, both of these are highest at 5wt.% La. Keywords CO methanation Syngas Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst La effect Thermal stability 1 Introduction The conversion of coal to synthetic natural gas (known as SNG) is a promising technology for the clean usage of coal [1–3]. The production of SNG is generally carried out via two steps: gasification of coal with steam and/or oxygen to generate syngas (synthetic gas, a mixture of H2 and CO) and methanation of CO with H2 (CO+3H2 →CH4 +H2O, ∆H298 0 =−206kJ/mol) Commercial scale production of SNG is carried out using an adiabatic multi-tubular reactor packed with an excess amount of catalyst at an inlet feed temperature of 300–350°C. Owing to the excessive exothermic nature of the reaction, however, the reaction temperature is known to increase to 800°C at a certain section of the reactor bed [4], and this hot zone gradually moves toward the downstream section with operation time. Moreover, the reaction mixture inside the reactor contains a significant amount of steam, which accelerates the thermal sintering of the catalyst. Therefore, for practical application of a catalyst, its durability under such high-severity conditions (high temperature with steam) is as important as the initial activity. Ni supported over γ-Al2O3 is often regarded as a preferable choice for large-scale production of SNG because of its comparable activity, high methane selectivity and relatively low cost [5–8]. However, it is not durable at high temperatures, especially in the presence of water vapor, because of the sintering of Ni particles [9–11]. High temperature also promotes a significant decrease in surface area of γ-alumina and/or the phase transformation to more stable phases of θ-, δ- and α-form, which results in the loss of catalytic activity [12–14]. Concerning the thermal sintering of the alumina support, it has been well known that La additive can retard both the sintering and phase transformation of γ-alumina [13,15–27]. The influence of various additives in Ni/Al2O3 catalysts has been widely explored to improve the activity and durability for the methanation of CO. Gelsthorpe et al. [28] reported that, through extensive screening tests with many additives, only La and Ce exhibited improvement in the catalytic activity whereas others such as Mg, Ca, Sr, Ba, Cu, Cr and Na had no effect or a negative effect. A later investigation by Rotgerink et al. with Ti [29], La [30], and Ce [31] and by Znak et al. [32] with Ce, La and Zr also proved the improvement in activity with La and Ce, which was explained by enhanced CO dissociation on the Ni surface. In addition to these, there have been many reports describing the effect of La as a physical promoter to improve the dispersion and reduction of Ni particles [33–41], and/or a chemical promoter to improve the catalytic activity for not only CO methanation but also hydrocarbon reforming reactions [30,42–46]. However, most works have mainly focused on the La effect on catalytic activity, and no investigation has focused on the long-term duration of Ni/alumina catalyst, especially under high-severity conditions (high temperature and high steam content) that exist in the industrial scale reactor. In this study, the effect of La addition to Mg-stabilized Ni/alumina was investigated for the methanation of CO with H2 [47,48], with a focus on both the activity and stability of the catalyst. The results of long-term ageing tests under high-severity conditions (850°C, space velocity=250,000h−1 and 40% steam in the feed) and various characterization on both fresh and aged catalysts have revealed that La acts as a chemical and physical promoter on both alumina and Ni to improve the activity and long-term stability of a catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation NiO-MgO-Al2O3 containing 20wt.% Ni and 10wt.% Mg was prepared by the co-precipitation method. Stoichiometric amounts of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in distilled water. Under vigorous stirring at 80°C, aqueous potassium carbonate was added drop by drop until the solution pH reached 10. The solution containing precipitate was aged at 80°C for another 4h. It was then filtered thoroughly with distilled water until the pH of the filtered solution became 7. This was followed by drying at 100°C overnight and subsequent calcination at 500°C for 4h. It was then ground and sieved to a size of 200mesh to obtain the powder form of NiO-MgO-Al2O3 catalyst. It was further impregnated with aqueous solution with various contents of La(NO3)3·6H2O to incipient wetness, dried at 100°C overnight, and calcined at 500°C for 4h. The prepared catalysts were denoted as xLa, where x represented the La content (0–10wt.%) in the calcined samples of La-NiO-MgO-Al2O3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 isotherms in both adsorption and desorption branches were obtained at liquid N2 temperature by using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Prior to the analysis, the catalyst sample was degassed in vacuum at 250°C for 2h to remove any physically adsorbed molecules. The specific surface area was obtained using the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) equation. The pore diameter distribution curve was derived from the desorption branch by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method assuming a cylindrical pore geometry. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was measured by using a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer. Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15418nm) was used in the 2θ scanning range of 10° and 80° at a speed of 0.04°min−1. The samples were reduced at 700°C for 4h under a flow of 50% H2 in N2 prior to the characterization. The mean crystallite diameter of Ni was estimated from the line broadening with the Scherrer equation with the peak of Ni (200) plane (2θ=51.8°) in the XRD pattern. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JOEL JEM-2200FS) was used to observe the particle morphology and measure the particle size and particle size distribution. A small amount of sample was dispersed in ethanol solution using an ultrasonic bath. The solution was mounted on a carbon-coated copper grid (150mesh) and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80°C for 3h. The particle size was measured directly through a suitable magnification of the TEM in several regions randomly selected from the sample. EELS (electron energy loss spectroscopy) analysis was also conducted to recognize Ni metal particles. Several hundreds of particles were counted for the determination of average particle diameter. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an ESCALAB 250 induced electron emission spectrometer with an Al Kα source (1486.8eV, 12mA, 20kV). The binding energy of La 3d and Ni 2p were calibrated with C 1s peak (BE=284.6eV) as a standard. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and CO chemisorption were carried out using a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics Autochem II). For the TPR analysis, 100mg of catalyst sample charged in a tubular reactor was heated under a flow of 5% H2 in Ar from 50 to 850°C at a constant heating rate of 10°C/min. The hydrogen consumption was monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the CO chemisorption measurement, the catalyst sample in the reactor was reduced in a flow of 10% H2 in He at 700°C for 4h and then flushed in pure He flow at 700°C for 1h before being cooled to the adsorption temperature (50°C). The CO adsorption isotherm was obtained until the catalyst surface became saturated using 5% CO in He. To calculate the Ni dispersion, the adsorption stoichiometry of CO/Nis was assumed to be 1 with a simplified assumption that CO molecules are chemisorbed linearly only [49], and all the Ni particles are in hemi-spherical shape [49,50]. H2 chemisorption measured by the same procedure described above, using 5% H2 in Ar. The adsorption stoichiometry of H/Nis was assumed to be 1 [50]. 2.3 Reaction tests Measurement of catalytic activity was carried out in a quartz tubular reactor packed with 200mg of catalyst at atmospheric pressure. Reactant with an H2/CO ratio of 3 in 10% N2 was fed at a space velocity of 100,000h−1. The reactor temperature was controlled by using a programmable temperature controller and detected by a movable thermocouple, positioned near the catalytic bed. Another thermocouple (1/16inch in OD) inserted inside the catalyst bed measured the reaction temperature of the catalyst bed. The catalyst was pretreated in a flow of 50% H2 in N2 at 700°C for 4h before the reaction test. Pellets (3mm D×3mmL) of 0La catalyst (Ni-Mg-Al2O3 without La) were tested separately in a bench scale reactor (1inch OD) at 335°C and 20bar after the reactor was packed with catalyst pellets 10cm in length. Reactant with a mole ratio of CO/H2 =1/3 in 20% N2 was fed at a space velocity of 10,000h−1. Analysis of the reaction products was conducted by means of a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with TCD and a column of a 60/80 Carboxen-1000 molecular sieve. The turnover frequency (TOF, s−1) was calculated by dividing the number of CO molecules reacted per second by the number of exposed Ni atoms on the surface that was titrated by CO chemisorption. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 La effect for fresh catalysts Table 1 shows the La effect on the textural properties (BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter) of fresh catalysts that were calcined at 500°C. As the La content increases, both BET and pore volume decrease gradually. When the La content exceeds 7wt.%, there exists a sudden drop in the pore volume with concomitant increase in the pore diameter, which is in agreement with previous report that at high content of La, La2O3 blocks smaller pores of alumina preferentially [42,51]. There have been many reports that La added to alumina behaves as a sintering inhibitor when alumina is exposed at high temperatures (i.e., 1000°C) [17,24,25,27]. The results in Table 1, however, have not shown any evidence that La acts as a sintering inhibitor. This is probably because our catalysts were calcined at a relatively low temperature of 500°C, not at 1000°C. Fig. 1 shows XRD peak patterns of La-added Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalysts after reduction at 700°C. Any crystalline phase of La, such as La2O3 or LaAlO3, was undetected in all samples. La has been known to exist as a lanthana monolayer or a two-dimensional over-layer on the alumina surface, which cannot be distinguished by XRD when the surface density of La is kept low—8.2–17.2μmol/m2 alumina, depending on the report [26,52,53]. These values correspond to the La content of 10.14–21.26wt.% in our catalyst. Therefore, even the maximum 10wt.% La in our catalyst would not have the crystalline structure of La. A close look at XRD peaks in Fig. 1 reveals that, upon increasing the La addition, peak broadening occurs for all of the peaks: peaks at 51.6° and 76.1° correspond to metallic Ni, and those at 37.1° 43.1°, and 62.6° correspond to either NiMgO2 or NiAl2O4. With the assumption that NiAl2O4 will not change its size because of the strong interaction of Ni with the alumina support, it is established that the addition of La effectively retards the sintering of both NiO and NiMgO2 particles. Fig. 2 shows TPR patterns of La-added Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalysts that were calcined at 500°C. The peak located in the low temperature region of 300–400°C (α-type) is generally accepted as free NiO species on the alumina support [48,54]: the one in the intermediate temperature range of 500–800°C (β-type) corresponds to NiO, which has stronger interaction with support [37,41,55], and the one at high temperatures above 800°C (γ-type) corresponds to an NiAl2O4 and/or NiMgO2 structure [40,56]. Thus, the metallic Ni formed after reduction at 700°C must have originated from α- and β-type species of NiO on the alumina support, not from either NiAl2O4 or NiMgO2. Upon increasing the La content, the α- and β-type peaks shift to a lower temperature, whereas the γ-type does not. For a qualitative analysis, the TPR profiles of the samples were de-convoluted, and the fractional area of each peaks are shown in Table 2 . After de-convoluting the three peaks, we have found that with increased La content, the peak area of the α-type peak (free NiO species) increases, whereas that of the β-type (Ni with a strong interaction with alumina) decreases. The results are in agreement with the previous observation that La weakens the interaction between NiO and Al2O3 by destroying partially metastable Ni-Al mixed oxide phase [37,57]. As expected, the area of γ-type that corresponds to NiAl2O4 is not influenced by the La addition because of the strong interaction between NiO and γ-Al2O3 [58]. The effect of the La addition on the particle size and surface properties of the Ni phase was investigated by means of XRD, TEM, chemisorption measurements of H2 and CO (the value in the parenthesis) as shown in Table 3 . The particle size of Ni measured by means of XRD is reduced with the addition of La. This decreasing effect is more pronounced at low La content (1–3wt.%), above which the size remains constant. The results of TEM show the same tendency as those of XRD, although the average size is slightly larger than that estimated by XRD. The enhancement of Ni dispersion by adding La has been observed in several studies. Cui et al. [59] and Gelsthorpe et al. [28] reported that the presence of the optimal amount of La increases the Ni dispersion. Zhang et al. [58] claimed that the enhancement of NiO dispersion can be achieved through the formation of La-Ni mixed oxide or separation of NiO micro-crystallites by the addition of La2O3. However, the addition of La may cover the Ni surface to decrease the number of Ni sites. The data in the 4th column of Table 3 represent the density of Ni sites per physical area of Ni surface. It was obtained by dividing the number of Ni sites measured by the H2 or CO chemisorption by the physical area obtained from XRD, which was calculated from mean crystallite diameter with the assumption of the hemispherical shape of Ni particles [60]. The value measured by using H2 chemisorption is slightly larger than that by CO chemisorption. It has been known that CO molecules adsorb on the Ni sites in both linear and bridged form. Our data of chemisorbed mole ratios of CO/H are in the range of 1.0 to 1.2, indicating that the majority of CO molecules are chemisorbed linearly as other authors adopted [50,61,62]. Anyhow, the data clearly show that, the addition of La decreases the density of Ni sites probably because La has covered the Ni surface. The loss of the Ni site density in the last column in Table 3 was defined as follows. L o s s o f N i s i t e d e n s i t y ( % ) = 1 − D e n s i t y o f N i s i t e s f o r L a − a d d e d c a t a l y s t D e n s i t y o f N i s i t e s f o r 0 L a × 100 This represents the percent of the Ni site density that is lost by the addition of La, after being compared to 0La. As we expect, the loss increases with increased La addition due to the covering of the Ni surface with La. The effect of La addition on the catalytic performance for the CO methanation is depicted in Fig. 3 . The selectivity to CH4 is independent of the La content, implying that the reaction pathway is unaffected by the La addition. The CO conversion shows a typical volcano type of curve, with a maximum value at 1La, which coincides with the largest number of exposed Ni sites per gram of catalyst observed at 1La in Table 3. The results establish that the H2 chemisorption site has a direct correspondence with the reaction site. The ignition temperature of the reaction was measured in the temperature range from 200°C to 300°C under the flow of diluted reactant (H2/CO ratio=3 in 50% N2 was fed at a space velocity of 120,000h−1). The ignition temperature exhibits an abrupt drop upon the addition of 1wt.% La (1La), and this is followed by a rather slow decrease upon further addition of La. The XPS measurements were conducted to determine the chemical state of La on Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The binding energy (BE) of La 3d5/2 in Fig. 4 (a) is found to be 835.0eV for catalysts having La content higher than 3wt%. This value is higher than the reported value of 834.3eV for La2O3 [22] and 833.8eV for LaAlO3 [63], with a much smaller ΔE value (3.4eV) between the primary and satellite peak than the reported value of 4.6eV for La2O3 [64]. The observed BE value of La 3d5/2 (835.0eV) is consistent with the values (835.3±4eV) reported by others [22,36,39,65,66]. who have suggested that La on the alumina surface exist as deficiently coordinated ‘dispersed La species’ acting as Lewis acid sites [65] at a low La content range (La/Al ratio ≤0.15). There have been reports that the dispersed La exist as hydroxide or carbonate-like species [22,24]. It is worthy to notice that no peak shift is observed for all the La contents, indicating that La exists in the form of ‘dispersed La species’ for all fresh samples. For the analysis of Ni 2p3/2 electron binding energy, deconvolution of the Ni 2p3/2 and La 3d3/2 was carefully conducted in the region of 845–870eV, and the results are depicted in Fig. 4(b). The La 3d3/2 spectra (dashed line in Fig. 4(b)) was estimated using the results of La 3d5/2 spectra (Fig. 4(a)) with the following assumptions: (i) identical shape, (ii) spin obit splitting value of 16.8eV, (iii) relative intensity ratio of 1.40 [67]. The Ni 2p3/2 spectra of 0La is composed of two different Ni species: one has BE at 852.7eV with a satellite peak at 860.1eV that is assigned to metallic Ni [41,68], and another has BE at 855.8eV with a satellite peak at 862.5eV that is assigned to Ni2+ [69]. The binding energy of Ni2+ (855.8eV) was higher than that of pure NiO (854.4eV [64]) and near that of NiAl2O4 (856.2eV [41,43]). It is generally accepted that the species with a higher binding energy value has the greater electronic interaction with support [68], which implies that the Ni species of 0La has a strong interaction with MgO and/or Al2O3, as suggested from TPR results. For the La-containing samples, there exists a clear peak shift to a lower value, suggesting the existence of La-Ni interaction. The BE of metallic Ni shifts negatively from 852.7 to 852.3eV with the addition of La, implying that La donated electrons to Ni because of the electropositive nature of La, thus Ni becomes more electron-rich state. Moreover, because La has a higher capacity to bind with electrons than Al [22], it could be suggested that Ni atoms surrounded by La becomes more dominant than Ni atoms surrounded by Al, which results in a weakened interaction between NiO and Al2O3 by the addition of La. The amount of shift is sensitive in the low range of La content (≤5wt.%) and becomes saturated at higher La content. Similar role of La as chemical promoter to modify the chemical state of metal has been reported for various noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Ru [70–77]. Bell and coworkers observed negative shift of Pd 3d5/2 binding energy on their Pd/La2O3 system [72], and have suggested that small patches of partially reduced ‘LaOx species’ on the surface of metal crystallites weaken the strength of CO adsorption by the back-donation of electrons from metal to CO [73,78]. Moreover, Schaper et al. [34] found that, through kinetic measurement of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, La reduced the heats of CO and H2 chemisorption. Znak et al. [32] also observed that CO dissociation rate on the Ni surface was considerably promoted on the presence of La. Since CO dissociation is generally accepted as a rate determining step in methantion reaction [50,79,80], La can increase the dissociation rate of CO on Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst to enhance the methanation activity. 3.2 La effect for aged catalysts To investigate the effect of La on the catalyst degradation during the CO methanation, the reaction was carried out using a bench-scale tubular reactor (1in. in diameter) that contained a 10cm bed length of pellets (3mmL×3 mmD) of Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst (0La). The reaction mixture (CO/H2 =1/3 with 20% N2) was fed at 335°C to the reactor, which was located inside a tubular furnace whose temperature was kept at 335°C. Fig. 5 (a) shows that the CO conversion and methane yield seem to be very stable during the 18days of operation with almost complete conversion of CO and 95% yield of methane. The temperature profile measured along the catalytic bed is presented in Fig. 5(b). As soon as the reactants enter the reactor, a sudden increase in temperature to 640°C is observed at the entrance of the reactor, after which the temperature decreases gradually along the reactor length to 370°C, indicating that the reaction occurs mostly at the entrance part because of its highly exothermic nature. After 18days of operation, the temperature at the entrance part decreases by 100°C, confirming that catalyst degradation has occurred at the entrance part because of the exposure at such a high temperature. Because this type of activity degradation is inevitable in a larger-scale commercial reactor, we focus on investigating the effect of La on the durability of Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst in high-severity conditions. Fig. 6 shows the effect of La addition on the CO conversion upon repeated ageing test under a severe hydrothermal condition. To accelerate the catalyst degradation, the ageing test was conducted by the following procedure. At first, the initial activity of fresh catalyst was measured at the following reaction conditions: T=320°C, H2/CO=3:1 with 10% N2, space velocity=100,000h−1. The ageing test was then conducted under higher severity conditions (T=850°C, 40% steam added in the feed, space velocity=250,000h−1) for 10h. The steps of the ageing test and activity measurement were repeated 4 or 8 times depending on the catalyst sample. The introduction of 40% of steam in the feed was intended to suppress carbon deposition at high temperature [81] and to accelerate catalyst sintering [82,83]. The results in Fig. 6 show that the initial activity for fresh catalysts is in the order of 1La>3La>0La−5La>7La>10La. The highest activity observed for 1La has a direct correspondence to the largest number of Ni sites on the surface for 1La as seen in Fig. 3, above which the number of Ni sites decreases owing to the increased La covering although the physical area of Ni increases by the addition of La. Unlike fresh catalysts, however, the aged catalysts exhibit quite different degradation patterns. During the period of the 1st ageing test, a faster degradation rate is observed at relatively low La contents range of 0–3wt.% (0–3La), and a slightly slower degradation rate for those with 7La and 10La. Noteworthy is the degradation pattern of 5La, which exhibits an improvement in the CO conversion from the beginning. The same trend of the activity improvement can be noticed, although the magnitude is weak, for 7La and 10La at much later stages of 20–40h. The un-promoted catalyst (0La) becomes deactivated completely after 60h of the ageing test. Its lifetime is shortened by half if the space velocity of the feed is doubled, establishing that the loss rate of the activity is proportional to the amount of product converted in the feed. The data in Table 4 show that 0La has lost 72.4% of the BET area and 52.5% in the density of the Ni sites after the ageing test, whereas La added catalysts have smaller degrees of losses. Moreover, TGA measurements show approximately 70% of the weight loss for the completely deactivated catalyst of 0La, whereas 5La has a weight gain of 5% probably due to oxidation of Ni. Therefore, the complete deactivation of 0La is caused a combined effect of the loss of the Ni site density and severe coke deposition. The BET data in Table 4 conclude that the La addition inhibits the thermal sintering of alumina. Many researchers have studied the La effect on the stabilization of alumina support [13,15–27]. The main contributor for retarding alumina sintering was attributed to the formation of lanthanum aluminate surface layer to lower the surface energy of alumina [15,53,63] or the anchoring and nucleation of La containing compound to highly reactive unsaturated Al atoms (strong Lewis acid sites) which is known to be effect even at very low La content [16,17,19,23,84]. There exists a saturation point on the La coverage as a dispersed state on the alumina surface. La Above the saturation, La forms either precipitated La2O3 crystalline phase or LaAlO3 perovskite structure depending on temperature [22,53]. Many researchers investigated the saturation of La for the monolayer coverage on the alumina surface by employing various measuring methods, and the results are summarized in Table 5 . The saturation point shows a wide variation in terms of the La surface density, depending on calcination temperature and analytical method. In general, data measured by XRD [23,52] or XPS [22,63] show high values (8.12–35.3μmol/m2 of alumina), whereas those measured by EXAFS [21,23] show low values of 1.49μmol/m2 alumina after calcination at 1000°C and 3.45μmol/m2 alumina after calcination at 800°C. Interestingly, several authors observed crystallization of La (or transition of La surface state) around 8.2μmol/m2 of alumina [22,23,53], which are close to the theoretical value of 5 La atoms/nm2 (corresponding to 8.31μmol/m2 of alumina) if the monolayer coverage of LaOx be assumed [84,85]. For comparison, Table 6 shows the surface density of La in our fresh and aged Ni-Mg/Al2O3 catalysts, after assuming that La has an even distribution on the surface of alumina. We have shown that La exists as a dispersed state for all fresh samples in previous XRD and XPS results, even for 10La having the maximum La density of 8.37μmol/m2 of alumina. LaAlO3 formation was found from 3La after catalysts experienced 40h of ageing, suggesting that part of La species aren’t completely isolated at La densities higher than 3.73μmol/m2 of alumina. Yamamoto et al. [23] has reported similar observation that La exists as isolated La species at temperatures below 1000°C if the La density is less than 1.49μmol/m2 of alumina, above which some La forms aggregates locally. Fresh catalyst with 5wt.% La (5La) corresponds to the La surface density of 3.73μmol/m2 alumina, which is near the saturation point of 3.45μmol/m2 alumina at 800°C measured by EXAFS [23]. We thus assume that on fresh catalyst, La exists as isolated state, up to 5wt.% La, above which some of La begins to form aggregates locally. The data in the last column of Table 4 represents the loss of the Ni site density that occurs during the period of the 40h ageing test. 0La has the largest loss (52.5%) of the Ni site density and the largest loss of the BET area (72.4%). We assume that thermal sintering during the ageing test results in the blockage of the pores and collapse of structure in the alumina support to hinder the chemisorption of H2 or CO molecules to the Ni sites. The loss of the Ni site density decreases as La loading increases, and, from 5La, it is changed suddenly to minus value that corresponds to the gain of the Ni site. The results imply to us that the dispersed La undergoes agglomeration to three dimensional amorphous aggregates or crystallites to expose the La-covered Ni sites. Fig. 6 shows that 5La exhibits the increase of CO conversion at an early stage of the ageing period, whereas 7La and 10La at much later stages. This is reasonable because 5La has faster agglomeration rate with only monolayer La, whereas 7La and 10La must have slower agglomeration rate with more portion of 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional La owing to the oversaturation of La on the Ni surface. It has been known that La acts as a chemical promoter to donate electrons to Ni so that the dissociation of CO can be facilitated to improve catalytic activity for the CO methanation [32,50,75]. Therefore, the existence of more dispersed La species on the Ni surface will enhance the catalytic activity of the Ni sites. Fig. 7 shows differences in the TOF values between fresh and aged catalysts as a function of La content. For fresh catalysts, TOF continues to increase with increasing La content up to 7wt.% La (7La). This is in agreement with the point at which the loss of the Ni site density becomes saturated at 7La as seen in the last column of Table 3. In other words, the covering degree of La on the Ni surface becomes saturated at 7La. For aged catalyst, the saturation point of TOF shifts to 5La due to the uncovering effect of La. Moreover, all the aged catalysts exhibit lower TOF values comparing with their fresh catalysts. The results confirm that La particle size is another important factor for governing the catalytic activity. It has suggested that La donate electrons from the ‘contact perimeter’ of the La particle to the neighboring Ni as suggested by Bell et al. [72–74]. Therefore, smaller particles, especially dispersed La in the fresh catalysts will have more influence than La agglomerates in the aged catalysts. 4 Conclusion The influence of La addition to Ni-Mg-alumina catalysts for the CO methanation has been investigated. Through reaction tests and characterization of physical and chemical state of fresh and long-term aged catalysts at high severity conditions, the following conclusions are drawn. La inhibits the thermal sintering of alumina even at 1wt.% of La loading and the inhibition action increases up to 5wt.% La loading. La covers not only the alumina but the Ni surface, and the covering degree of Ni is kept increasing with increased La loading. La exists as dispersed state of monolayer up to 5wt% La (3.73μmol La/m2 of Al2O3). Upon ageing at 800°C for 40h, 0La catalyst experiences 72.4% loss of BET area, owing to the blockage of pores and collapse of the structure in the alumina support. Such a big loss of BET results in an appreciable loss (52.5%) in the density of the surface Ni sites that is defined by dividing the number of Ni atoms titrated with chemisorbed hydrogen by physical surface area of Ni. With the increased La addition, the density loss of the Ni sites during ageing test becomes less and less, and then an inversion of the loss (the gain) is observed from 5La, which is caused by the uncovering effect through agglomeration of the dispersed La to amorphous aggregates and crystallites. This kind of gain in the Ni sites with high La loadings leads an enhancement of the catalytic activity. Thus, the highest activity that is observed with 1La for fresh catalysts moves to 5La for aged catalysts. TOF for the CO methanation is higher with catalyst having smaller particle size of La than that having larger size, since La donates electrons to Ni through the perimeter of the La particle. coredata.dc:description: Various contents of La (1–10wt.%) were added to Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalyst to improve its catalytic activity and long-term stability for CO methanation. The optimum amount of La for the highest CO conversion is obtained at 1wt.% La addition for fresh catalysts, whereas at 5wt.% La for aged catalyst. During a long term ageing test at a high severity condition (850°C, space velocity=250,000h−1 and 40% steam in the feed), catalysts having 0–3wt% La rapidly lose their activity at the initial 10h period due to the sintering of Ni particles, and this is followed by slower degradation due to the thermal sintering of the support alumina. Catalysts having higher La contents (5–10wt.%) exhibit an increase in the CO conversion at a certain period, which is attributed to the uncovering effect of La on the Ni surface through the agglomeration of dispersed La into aggregates. For fresh catalysts, the CO conversion and turnover frequency are highest at 1wt.% La and 7wt.% La, respectively. For aged catalysts, both of these are highest at 5wt.% La.
coredata.dc:title: La effect on the long-term durability of Ni-Mg-Al2O3 catalysts for syngas methanation
